frame.name: FR_Making_speech
frame.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Speaker</fen> utters a <fen>Speech</fen>. The words to refer to the <fen>Speech</fen> do not describe the semantics of the content of the message, but are classes of speech. <ex></ex> <ex>FR-EX: <fex name="Speaker">Pauline</fex> a <t>prononcé</t> <fex name="Speech">une phrase, un discours, des paroles</fex></ex> <ex></ex> This frame is used for LUs for which the message is referred to by a noun of speech, but not by a noun referring to the semantic content of the message nor a sentence. It differs from Reading_aloud, in which a text is read. It differs from Text_creation, in which a written text or oral speech is explicitely created. For the FR_Making_speech, whether the Speaker is the author of the Speech is not specified. <ex></ex>
<asf>Relation to fndata-1.5</asf> : New in fndata-asfalda.
<ex></ex> Distinctions with other frames: <ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>Spelling_and_pronouncing</frframe>: The Spelling_and_pronouncing frame contains the idea of judgment of how something should or is usually pronounced, leading to the expression of the Formal_realization FE.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>Reading_aloud</frframe>: In Reading_aloud, a text is read.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>Text_creation</frframe>: In Text_creation, a written text or oral speech is explicitely created.
<ex></ex>
≠ <frframe>FR_Statement-manner-noise</frframe>: the LUs in FR_Making_speech can be used only with message characterized using a speech name, not using terms referring to the semantics of the message (but for FR_Statement-manner-noise, both cases are possible).
</def-root>

FE.name: Speaker
FE.definition: <def-root>The person who orally delivers a message about a <fen>Topic</fen> to an <fen>Audience</fen>. </def-root>
